Inhibition of GSK3 does not interfere with the ability of rapamycin to inhibit mTORC1 signaling and cap binding , but blocks rapamycin induced reduction of cyclin D1 , c-Myc and Mcl-1 .
GSK3 inhibition rescued rapamcyin induced reduction of several oncogenic proteins such as cyclin D1 , Mcl-1 and c-Myc , without interfering with the ability of rapamycin to suppress mTORC1 signaling and cap binding .
Acute or short-time treatment of cancer cells with rapamycin induces mTORC2 dissociation accompanied with reduction of cyclin D1 , c-Myc and Mcl-1 .
These results together indicate that inhibition of GSK3 does not interfere with the ability of rapamycin to inhibit the mTORC1 signaling .
Hence , it is clear that inhibition of GSK3 attenuates the ability of RAD001 to inhibit the growth of lung cancer xenografts in nude mice , indicating that GSK3 activity is also critical for rapalogs ' antitumor activity in vivo .

With respect to surface protein levels , we found that CD24 expression was downregulated by all the Ras effector mutants , including RasV12G37 , when compared to control cells . ++++ Ras is an oncogene with mutations present in approximately 30 % of all human cancers and has been shown to repress CD24 surface expression . ++++ Therefore , further work is necessary to identify the precise regulatory mechanism used by Ras to repress CD24 transcription . ++++ Since we observed that CD24 mRNA and protein expression are downregulated by Ras , we next asked which pathways downstream of Ras are sufficient to suppress CD24 expression . ++++ We have demonstrated that CD24 expression is directly suppressed by oncogenic Ras , however , while inhibition of the MEK was sufficient to partially restore CD24 expression at the mRNA level , inhibition of Raf was necessary to increase CD24 + cells . ++++ Thus , these data clearly demonstrate that the oncogenic Ras mediated suppression of CD24 expression is regulated at multiple levels .
Surprisingly , inhibition of Raf but not MEK or PI3K significantly increased CD24 surface expression . ++++ Therefore , even though activation of the Raf pathway is sufficient to decrease CD24 mRNA and protein , inhibition of oncogenic Raf and MEK signaling does not restore CD24 expression to the level of control cells at the mRNA or protein level . ++++ Surprisingly , inhibition of the Raf pathway , at the level of MEK or Raf , or the PI3K pathway , at the level of PI3K , either separately or together , was not sufficient to fully restore CD24 expression in RasV12 cells . ++++ In contrast , inhibition of Raf with sorafenib did not restore CD24 mRNA expression but significantly increased the proportion of RasV12 cells expressing CD24 .
Surprisingly , inhibition of Raf but not MEK or PI3K significantly increased CD24 surface expression . ++++ Surprisingly , inhibition of MEK with U0126 only partially restored CD24 mRNA expression but not surface protein expression . ++++ We have demonstrated that CD24 expression is directly suppressed by oncogenic Ras , however , while inhibition of the MEK was sufficient to partially restore CD24 expression at the mRNA level , inhibition of Raf was necessary to increase CD24 + cells .
Similar to our previous observations , we found that treatment of RasV12 with LY294002 reduced phosphorylation of Akt with no effect on phosphorylation of ERK . ++++ Similarly , RasV12 cells treated with LY294002 had reduced phosphorylation of Akt with no effect on ERK phosphorylation .

Despite evidence that overexpression of oncogenic Ras can repress CD24 surface expression the mechanism for this regulation of CD24 is not known . ++++ Here , we have demonstrated that expression of oncogenic Ras is sufficient to directly downregulate expression of CD24 at the mRNA and protein levels as well as repress promoter activity .

This study indicates that FAK contributes APC driven intestinal tumorigenesis through its kinase activity . ++++ Overall , these results strongly support that FAK and PYK2 kinase contributes to APC driven intestinal tumorigenesis through phosphorylating GSK3beta Y216 to promote Wnt and beta-catenin signaling .
Overall , these results strongly support that FAK and PYK2 kinase contributes to APC driven intestinal tumorigenesis through phosphorylating GSK3beta Y216 to promote Wnt and beta-catenin signaling . ++++ If so , it explains why inhibition of FAK by intestinal deletion of FAK was sufficient to suppress tumor development , it also explains why PF562271 treatment inhibited PYK2 elevation in APC min/+ mice ( XREF_FIG , left panel ) .
We next validated the role of GSK3beta Y216 in Wnt and beta-catenin signaling in GSK3beta knockout ( KO ) MEFs ( mouse embryonic fibroblasts ) . ++++ Our results has uncovered a previously unrealized role of GSK3beta Y216 phosphorylation : it triggers GSK3beta recruitment of beta-TrCP and subsequent GSK3beta monoubiquitination by beta-TrCP , an event required for Wnt induced inhibition of beta-catenin degradation , thus identifying phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 as an ' activator ' of the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway .
FAK and PYK2 kinase activity mediates FAK and PYK2 regulation of the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway .

FAK and PYK2 kinase activity mediates FAK and PYK2 regulation of the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway .
Although APC mutation is believed to activate Wnt signaling constitutively , histopathological studies show that only about 50 % colon carcinoma cells display homogeneous nuclear beta-catenin staining , a surrogate for Wnt signaling activity , indicating that APC mutation alone is not sufficient to cause persistent or full activation of the Wnt pathway in CRC cells , therefore Wnt signaling is regulatable in APC mutated CRCs .

Our results has uncovered a previously unrealized role of GSK3beta Y216 phosphorylation : it triggers GSK3beta recruitment of beta-TrCP and subsequent GSK3beta monoubiquitination by beta-TrCP , an event required for Wnt induced inhibition of beta-catenin degradation , thus identifying phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 as an ' activator ' of the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway . ++++ We previously found that Wnt simulation induces monoubiquitination of GSK3beta by beta-TrCP , which is required for Wnt induced inhibition of beta-catenin recruitment of beta-TrCP and subsequent stabilization of beta-catenin .
Together , these results reveal that FAK and PYK2 mediate GSK3 Y279 and Y216 phosphorylation in CRC cells . ++++ However , in DLD-1 cells expressing FAK and PYK2 , simultaneous KD of both kinases were required to inhibit GSK3 Y279 and Y216 phosphorylation and to reduce the level of beta-catenin ( XREF_FIG ) , strongly suggesting that FAK and PYK2 function redundantly to phosphorylate GSK3 Y279 and Y216 to promote Wnt and beta-catenin signaling .

In Wnt-off state , the cytosolic level of beta-catenin is kept low by its continuous degradation : beta-catenin is phosphorylated by GSK3 on serine 33 and 37 and threonine 41 , phosphorylation then triggers beta-catenin recruitment of ubiquitin E3 beta-TrCP ( beta-transducin repeats containing proteins ) , causing its ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation .
Inhibition of FAK and PYK2 suppresses intestinal phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 and adenoma formation in APC min/+ mice .
Inhibition of FAK and PYK2 suppresses intestinal phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 and adenoma formation in APC min/+ mice .
The kinase activity per se of GSK3 plays a dual role in Wnt signaling : GSK3 phosphorylation of Wnt coreceptor LRP6 on its PPPSP motifs is required for the activation of the pathway ( positive role ) , whereas phosphorylation of beta-catenin by GSK3 triggers its degradation ( negative role ) .
In Wnt-off state , the cytosolic level of beta-catenin is kept low by its continuous degradation : beta-catenin is phosphorylated by GSK3 on serine 33 and 37 and threonine 41 , phosphorylation then triggers beta-catenin recruitment of ubiquitin E3 beta-TrCP ( beta-transducin repeats containing proteins ) , causing its ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation .
Newly synthesized beta-catenin then accumulates and enters the nucleus to interact with transcription factors TCF ( T-cell factor )/LEF ( lymphoid enhancing factor ) to activate transcription of the Wnt target genes .

In line with a prior report that GSK3beta Y216 can be phosphorylated by PYK2 , we found that treatment of HEK293T cells with PF-562271 , a dual inhibitor of FAK and PYK2 , inhibited GSK3beta Y216 and GSK3alpha Y279 phosphorylation in the presence and absence of Wnt3a ( XREF_FIG ) .
In line with a prior report that GSK3beta Y216 can be phosphorylated by PYK2 , we found that treatment of HEK293T cells with PF-562271 , a dual inhibitor of FAK and PYK2 , inhibited GSK3beta Y216 and GSK3alpha Y279 phosphorylation in the presence and absence of Wnt3a ( XREF_FIG ) .

Our results indicate that phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 by FAK and PYK2 is a molecular determinant of GSK3beta recruitment of beta-TrCP , and is required for the activation of the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway and crucial for Wnt driven intestinal tumorigenesis .
Our results has uncovered a previously unrealized role of GSK3beta Y216 phosphorylation : it triggers GSK3beta recruitment of beta-TrCP and subsequent GSK3beta monoubiquitination by beta-TrCP , an event required for Wnt induced inhibition of beta-catenin degradation , thus identifying phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 as an ' activator ' of the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway .

We previously showed that Wnt induced beta-catenin accumulation requires Wnt induced GSK3beta and beta-TrCP interaction ; the current study revealed that phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 was a molecular determinant of GSK3beta recruitment of beta-TrCP .

The kinase activity per se of GSK3 plays a dual role in Wnt signaling : GSK3 phosphorylation of Wnt coreceptor LRP6 on its PPPSP motifs is required for the activation of the pathway ( positive role ) , whereas phosphorylation of beta-catenin by GSK3 triggers its degradation ( negative role ) .
Here we report a novel FAK/PYK2/GSK3beta Y216 / beta-catenin regulation axis : FAK and PYK2 , elevated in adenomas in APC min/+ mice and in human colorectal cancer tissues , functioned redundantly to promote the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway by phosphorylating GSK3beta Y216 to reinforce pathway output -- beta-catenin accumulation and intestinal tumorigenesis .
FAK and PYK2 promotes the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway and intestinal tumorigenesis by phosphorylating GSK3beta .

Our results indicate that phosphorylation of GSK3beta Y216 by FAK and PYK2 is a molecular determinant of GSK3beta recruitment of beta-TrCP , and is required for the activation of the Wnt and beta-catenin pathway and crucial for Wnt driven intestinal tumorigenesis .
Further , while tumor cells do not effectively target betacat for destruction , it is less clear at what step destruction is blocked by APC truncation .
Thus these studies suggest that Wnt signaling leads to either reduction in the rate of betacat phosphorylation by the destruction complex , or that it inhibits a key regulated step after phosphorylation , perhaps transfer to the E3 ligase , thus turning down an intact destruction complex , leading to high levels of betacat .

Since GSK3 activity is inhibited by Wnt signaling , key residues in R2 and B that drive APC : Axin interaction dynamics would no longer be phosphorylated .
Interestingly , while Axin reduced total betacat levels ( XREF_FIG ) , betacat was further reduced in cells expressing both APC2 and Axin ( XREF_FIG ) suggesting that APC2 promotes more effective destruction complex activity .
Our hypothesis suggests phosphorylation of R2/B promotes release of APC2 's Arm rpts from the Axin complex , and that this would be essential for the catalytic cycle of the destruction complex -- thus mutating these putative GSK3 phosphorylation sites in motif B would reduce APC2 function in helping mediate betacat destruction .
Since removing R2/B restored APC and Axin interaction even in the absence of the SAMPs ( XREF_FIG ) , we hypothesized R2/B negatively regulates APC2 Armrpt : Axin interaction and that release of this interaction is essential to allow phosphorylated betacat to be moved on to destruction .
Interestingly , while Axin reduced total betacat levels ( XREF_FIG ) , betacat was further reduced in cells expressing both APC2 and Axin ( XREF_FIG ) suggesting that APC2 promotes more effective destruction complex activity .
A destruction complex operating at reduced levels could lead to high enough betacat levels to activate Wnt target genes but could maintain low enough levels to be quickly shut down when needed ; it would also prevent the apoptosis seen in some cell types at extremely high betacat levels .
We also tested whether proteasome inhibition might trigger enlargement of the APC + Axin complexes -- this also did not further increase puncta size or further decrease puncta number ( XREF_FIG ) .
Together these data support the hypothesis that APC2 enhances Axin 's ability to promote betacat destruction . ++++ These data further support the hypothesis that APC2 enhances Axin 's ability to promote betacat destruction . ++++ These data suggest APC2 may enhance assembly of Axin oligomers , stimulating formation of larger complexes .
We thus hypothesized that APC enhances Axin 's ability to promote betacat exit from the destruction complex , and thus the destruction complex 's betacat throughput . ++++ Our data suggest APC plays two roles : ( 1 ) APC promotes efficient Axin multimerization through one known and one novel APC : Axin interaction site , and ( 2 ) GSK3 acts through APC motifs R2 and B to regulate APC : Axin interactions , promoting high-throughput of betacatenin to destruction .
Taken together , however , our data suggest that GSK3 acts in part through R2 and B to promote release of APC2 's Arm rpts from the Axin complex . ++++ These data suggest that GSK3 activity promotes release of APC2 's Arm rpts from the Axin complex .
Axin puncta are dynamic protein assemblies , and the Wnt effector Dishevelled significantly increases Axin dynamics in puncta , suggesting it negatively regulates Axin self association , consistent with its known negative regulatory role in destruction complex function .

Further , neither APC2DeltaArm nor APC2DeltaSAMPs increased Axin puncta size or reduced Axin puncta number ( XREF_FIG ) .
APC , a key negative regulator of Wnt signaling in development and oncogenesis , acts in the destruction complex with the scaffold Axin and the kinases GSK3 and CK1 to target betacatenin for destruction .
These data suggest that R2 and B regulate APC2 dynamics in the destruction complex and that APC2 lacking them can not effectively support Axin in targeting betacat for destruction .
We hypothesize this induces a conformational change in APC2 that releases the Arm rpts from association with Axin ( step 4 ) ; since only a subset of APC2 molecules in the destruction complex would release the Arm rpts at any given time , the overall destruction complex would remain stable .
Interestingly , coexpressing APC2 substantially altered the structure of many complexes , increasing the length and complexity of Axin cables ( XREF_FIG = three representative puncta ; Videos 4-6 show 3D reconstructions ) , with APC2 and Axin cables intertwined and in some puncta APC bridging Axin cables ( XREF_FIG , arrows ) .
One intriguing study proposed that APC acts in the destruction complex to protect betacat from dephosphorylation and then targets it to the E3 ligase .
Further , neither APC2DeltaArm nor APC2DeltaSAMPs increased Axin puncta size or reduced Axin puncta number ( XREF_FIG ) .
The level of Axin over-expression needed to trigger more prominent Axin puncta is not dramatic -- for example , treatment of SW480 cells with tankyrase inhibitors increased levels of AXIN1 3-5x and AXIN2 5-20x and this was sufficient to trigger formation of Axin puncta .
Our data further suggested that R2/B negatively regulates APC and Axin interaction , a somewhat surprising role for an essential part of the destruction complex .
We hypothesized that R2/B phosphorylation by GSK3 is a key step in APC2 's mechanism to target betacat for destruction . ++++ Thus we tested whether R2/B can be phosphorylated by GSK3 . ++++ Perhaps R2/B phosphorylation by GSK3 regulates association of alpha-catenin with APC , and its binding induces alterations in APC : Axin interactions . ++++ If GSK3 phosphorylation of R2/B antagonizes Arm rpts : Axin association , inhibiting GSK3 should increase colocalization of APC2DeltaSAMPs with Axin , as did deleting R2 or B ( XREF_FIG ) .
In the current model , betacat is recruited into the destruction complex by binding APC or Axin and sequentially phosphorylated by CK1 and GSK3 . ++++ GSK3 , which phosphorylates betacat , Axin and other sites on APC , also phosphorylates APC2 's R2 and B ( step 3 ; CK1 may also be involved , as it is in the other phosphorylation events in the complex ) .
Since removing R2/B restored APC and Axin interaction even in the absence of the SAMPs ( XREF_FIG ) , we hypothesized R2/B negatively regulates APC2 Armrpt : Axin interaction and that release of this interaction is essential to allow phosphorylated betacat to be moved on to destruction .
In the destruction complex , GSK3 and CK1 phosphorylate not only betacat but also Axin and other sites on APC .
GSK3 , which phosphorylates betacat , Axin and other sites on APC , also phosphorylates APC2 's R2 and B ( step 3 ; CK1 may also be involved , as it is in the other phosphorylation events in the complex ) .
Motifs R2 and B include highly conserved serine and threonines matching the GSK3 and CK1 consensuses , and this region is phosphorylated by GSK3 in vitro .
In the destruction complex , GSK3 and CK1 phosphorylate not only betacat but also Axin and other sites on APC .
In the current model , betacat is recruited into the destruction complex by binding APC or Axin and sequentially phosphorylated by CK1 and GSK3 .
mTOR is present in two distinct complexes , mTORC1 and mTORC2 , both of which can be inhibited by the KU compound .
Dynamin 2 has been shown to play an important role in tubule scission at lysosomes , and the use of the dynamin inhibitor dynasore rapidly induces a similar LAMP1 positive tubular phenotype .
mTOR is present in two distinct complexes , mTORC1 and mTORC2 , both of which can be inhibited by the KU compound .
In contrast to KU , the specific mTORC1 inhibitor rapamycin only partially blocked the mobility shift of UVRAG , as it did for 4E-BP1 also , indicating that residual UVRAG phosphorylation may be due to the rapamycin-insensitive properties of mTORC1 .
We also found that mTOR inhibition reduced VPS34 activity , which is consistent with the previously published work from other groups . ++++ This could suggest that these tubules are different in nature to the ALR tubules or that inhibition of the mTOR activated VPS34 impairs the selectivity mechanism , for example by simply allowing the tubules to persist attached to the originating lysosome .
However , there is little evidence to suggest that VPS34 and its product PI ( 3 ) P also act directly at the lysosome itself . ++++ By nature of its involvement in lysosomal trafficking pathways , VPS34 has an indirect role on lysosomal function ; however , we were curious to examine whether VPS34 and its product PI ( 3 ) P play a more direct role in regulating lysosomal function , thus providing a mechanism for coordination of not only these distinct trafficking pathways , but also their common end point .
However , there is little evidence to suggest that VPS34 and its product PI ( 3 ) P also act directly at the lysosome itself . ++++ By nature of its involvement in lysosomal trafficking pathways , VPS34 has an indirect role on lysosomal function ; however , we were curious to examine whether VPS34 and its product PI ( 3 ) P play a more direct role in regulating lysosomal function , thus providing a mechanism for coordination of not only these distinct trafficking pathways , but also their common end point .
UVRAG has been shown to enhance VPS34 activity .
This is supported by the fact that lysosomes are still acidified in UVRAG phospho-mutant cells ( Fig XREF_FIG ) .
In contrast to KU , the specific mTORC1 inhibitor rapamycin only partially blocked the mobility shift of UVRAG , as it did for 4E-BP1 also , indicating that residual UVRAG phosphorylation may be due to the rapamycin-insensitive properties of mTORC1 .
VPS34 catalyses the phosphorylation of phosphatidylinositol ( PI ) at the three position of the inositol ring to produce phosphatidylinositol 3-phosphate ( PI ( 3 ) P ) .
To investigate the possibility that mTOR regulates VPS34 , we examined lysates from three different cell lines ( HeLa , U2OS and MEF ) grown under control conditions , treated with the mTOR inhibitor KU or incubated in amino acid-free Earle 's balanced salt solution ( EBSS ) , which also results in mTOR inhibition ( Fig XREF_FIG ) .
Given that VPS34 inhibition with VPS34-IN1 prolonged auto-lysosomal tubulation , which in turn was blocked by mTOR inhibition , we explored the possibility that mTOR may directly control VPS34 activity .
This in turn induces bulk transport of autophagosomes and their contents to lysosomes , generating large autolysosomes .
The increased rate of cell death upon starvation in the dblA UVRAG cells does indeed suggest ALR tubulation is essential in maintaining lysosomal function and cell survival , especially as this can be reversed by mTOR inhibition .
It is important to note that mTOR inhibition does not reduce all pools of PI ( 3 ) P .
Taken together , the data currently suggest that persistent lysosomal tubulation , caused by loss of mTOR mediated UVRAG phosphorylation , severely impedes cell survival and that the regeneration of lysosomes following starvation is critical to this process . ++++ As can be seen in Fig XREF_FIG , LAMP1 structures stained with lysotracker with approximately equal intensity in either WT or dblA UVRAG expressing cells , suggesting global lysosomal acidification was not impaired by loss of mTOR mediated UVRAG phosphorylation .
lambda Phosphatase caused a mobility shift but this was prevented in the presence of phosphatase inhibitors , confirming that UVRAG is indeed phosphorylated under conditions where mTOR is active .
UVRAG dblA reduced mTOR mediated phosphorylation by ~ 70 % , similar to that of wild-type ( WT ) UVRAG phosphorylation in the presence of KU ( Fig XREF_FIG ) .
mTOR mediated UVRAG phosphorylation enhances cell survival following long-term starvation . ++++ Taken together , the data currently suggest that persistent lysosomal tubulation , caused by loss of mTOR mediated UVRAG phosphorylation , severely impedes cell survival and that the regeneration of lysosomes following starvation is critical to this process . ++++ Depletion of endogenous UVRAG in cells expressing siRNA resistant GFP-UVRAG ( either WT or dblA ) did not cause any noticeable change in the degradation of EGFR upon EGF stimulation ( Fig XREF_FIG ) , implying mTOR mediated UVRAG phosphorylation does not disrupt trafficking to the lysosome or its degradative capacity . ++++ To confirm that mTOR can phosphorylate UVRAG , we carried out in vitro kinase assays using RAPTOR immunoprecipitation ( IP ) as a source of endogenous mTORC1 complex . ++++ As can be seen in Fig XREF_FIG , LAMP1 structures stained with lysotracker with approximately equal intensity in either WT or dblA UVRAG expressing cells , suggesting global lysosomal acidification was not impaired by loss of mTOR mediated UVRAG phosphorylation . ++++ Given that our original observation showed that VPS34 activity was important in mTOR dependent lysosomal tubulation ( Fig XREF_FIG ) , we examined whether mTOR phosphorylation of UVRAG altered VPS34 activity .
Autoradiography to detect 32 P incorporation into substrates revealed that UVRAG is highly phosphorylated by mTORC1 at a level that was greater than the known substrate p70S6K . ++++ We did identify S498 of UVRAG as being phosphorylated in cells ; however , unlike S550 and S571 , this was not affected by mTOR inhibition and mutation of this site did not reduce endogenous mTORC1 phosphorylation of UVRAG in vitro ( XREF_SUPPLEMENTARY ) . ++++ Combined , the in vitro and cell data clearly indicate that mTORC1 phosphorylates UVRAG at two distinct sites .
Taken together with the in vitro data , this suggests that mTOR mediated UVRAG phosphorylation at S550 and S571 enhances VPS34 activity .
We do note that during the submission of this manuscript , a paper was published describing mTOR phosphorylation of UVRAG at serine 498 ( S498 ) However , phosphorylation inhibited VPS34 activity through enhanced RUBICON binding and decreased trafficking of endosomes and autophagosomes to the lysosome .
mTOR activates the VPS34 and UVRAG complex to regulate autolysosomal tubulation and cell survival .
We do note that during the submission of this manuscript , a paper was published describing mTOR phosphorylation of UVRAG at serine 498 ( S498 ) However , phosphorylation inhibited VPS34 activity through enhanced RUBICON binding and decreased trafficking of endosomes and autophagosomes to the lysosome .

mTOR phosphorylates the UVRAG-VPS34 lipid kinase complex .
Consistent with the data presented here , mTOR inhibition has previously been shown to inhibit total levels of cellular PI ( 3 ) P ; our data now demonstrate this inhibition is due to UVRAG dephosphorylation .

However , EP2 overexpression in the absence of PGE 2 induced an increase in the level of p38 phosphorylation as well as the kinase activity of p38 , suggesting that up-regulation of EP2 may promote p38 activation via non G protein coupled pathway . ++++ Overexpression of EP2 induced p38 phosphorylation is not dependent on the activation of heterotrimeric G protein . ++++ In our experiments , overexpression of EP2 significantly induced phosphorylation of p38 , while it had marginal effect on Erk phosphorylation . ++++ EP2 overexpression induces phosphorylation of p38 in a Src dependent manner . ++++ In order to provide the evidence that EP2 overexpression specifically induces p38 phosphorylation , we measured the effect of EP2 overexpression on Erk phosphorylation . ++++ We further showed that EP2 overexpression induces phosphorylation of p38 via Src and that EP2 forms a complex with Src and beta-arrestin . ++++ The most significant increases in PGE 2 -induced Erk phosphorylation were observed in EP1- and EP3 transfected cells , while PGE 2 treatment slightly increased Erk phosphorylation in EP2 transfected cells , suggesting that EP2 overexpression specifically promotes the phosphorylation of p38 . ++++ EP2 overexpression increases the phosphorylation of p38 in HEK 293 cells in a PGE 2 -independent manner .

However , treatment with AG1478 , a potent EGFR kinase inhibitor , did not affect EP2 induced p38 phosphorylation and overexpression of EGFR marginally affected p38 phosphorylation compared to Src ( data not shown ) , suggesting that EP2 induced p38 phosphorylation does not involve EGFR pathway .
These results demonstrate that EP2 induces the phosphorylation and the activation of Src .
These results indicate that the EP2 induced p38 phosphorylation may be mediated by Src .

Recently , we found that also the checkpoint kinase Chk2 and the proteasome activator REGgamma are required for efficient CCAR2 mediated inhibition of SIRT1 and induction of p53 dependent apoptosis . ++++ Notably , these events are not mediated by CCAR2 dependent inhibition of SIRT1 , the main CCAR2 target in the DNA damage response [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] , but , instead , they seem to be dependent on defective Chk2 activity regulation .
Next , we assessed in these cells the repair of DNA damages induced by etoposide treatment , a chemotherapeutic drug that inhibits topoisomerase II , finally inducing double strand breaks ( DSBs ) , and that is known to strongly promote ATM and ATR dependent phosphorylation of CCAR2 and apoptosis [ XREF_BIBR ] .
Besides SIRT1 , CCAR2 inhibits the activity of the histone modifying enzymes SUV39H1 and HDAC3 [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] , thus playing an important role in chromatin structure regulation .

Since SIRT1 is the main CCAR2 target in the DNA damage response , we verified whether this protein could have some role in CCAR2 mediated DNA repair . ++++ Notably , these events are not mediated by CCAR2 dependent inhibition of SIRT1 , the main CCAR2 target in the DNA damage response [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] , but , instead , they seem to be dependent on defective Chk2 activity regulation .

Since SIRT1 is the main CCAR2 target in the DNA damage response , we verified whether this protein could have some role in CCAR2 mediated DNA repair .
To investigate if accumulation of cells with unrepaired DNA breaks in CCAR2 ablated cells could be due to alterations of cell cycle progression induced by CCAR2 absence , we performed FACS analyses [ XREF_BIBR ] of U2OS CCAR2 +/+ and CCAR2-/- cells , before and after damage , and found similar cell cycle profile in both cell lines ( XREF_SUPPLEMENTARY ) .

The CCAR2 dependent failure of DNA repair is caused by defective Chk2 activity .
Upon DNA damage , the apical checkpoint kinases ATM and ATR phosphorylate CCAR2 on T454 , enhancing its inhibitory binding to the histone deacetylase SIRT1 , promoting p53 acetylation and p53 dependent apoptosis [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] . ++++ Upon DNA damage , the apical checkpoint kinases ATM and ATR phosphorylate CCAR2 on T454 , enhancing its inhibitory binding to the histone deacetylase SIRT1 , promoting p53 acetylation and p53 dependent apoptosis [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] .
To verify the specificity of these events , we transfected U2OS-CCAR2-/- cells with vectors encoding CCAR2 WT , CCAR2 T454A , FLAG-Chk2 WT and FLAG-Chk2 KD ( kinase dead , a catalytically inactive mutant ) and , after etoposide treatment , we found that expression of CCAR2 ( both the wild type and , to a lesser extent , the T454A mutant ) and wild type Chk2 restores KAP1-S473 phosphorylation , but not the expression of Chk2 KD , indicating that the defective KAP1 phosphorylation on S473 is caused by CCAR2 deficiency which in turn affects Chk2 activity .
Upon DNA lesions , CCAR2 is phosphorylated by the apical kinases ATM and ATR and this phosphorylation enhances CCAR2 binding to SIRT1 , leading to SIRT1 inhibition , p53 acetylation and p53 dependent apoptosis .
Conversely , the expression of CCAR2 WT led to a twofold increase in Chk2-pT387 signal , and almost a similar increase was seen by the expression of CCAR2 T454A phosphomutant [ XREF_BIBR ] , clearly indicating that , in human cells , CCAR2 positively regulates Chk2 autophosphorylation .
However , neither the phosphorylation of Chk2-T68 nor that of KAP1-S824 was influenced by CCAR2 overexpression , a finding consistent with the autophosphorylation of ATM-S1981 , which is unaffected by CCAR2 ( XREF_SUPPLEMENTARY ) .

As Chk2 phosphorylation of KAP1-S473 induces the mobilization of HP1 from heterochromatin and promotes chromatin relaxation [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] , we investigated whether the defects in heterochromatic DNA repair in CCAR2 deficient cells was somewhat linked to Chk2 .
In particular , Chk2 phosphorylates KAP1 on Ser473 decreasing the interaction between KAP1 and HP1 proteins : this post translational modification promotes HP1beta mobilization and the reorganization of chromatin structure favoring the repair of DNA breaks inside heterochromatin [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] .
To verify the specificity of these events , we transfected U2OS-CCAR2-/- cells with vectors encoding CCAR2 WT , CCAR2 T454A , FLAG-Chk2 WT and FLAG-Chk2 KD ( kinase dead , a catalytically inactive mutant ) and , after etoposide treatment , we found that expression of CCAR2 ( both the wild type and , to a lesser extent , the T454A mutant ) and wild type Chk2 restores KAP1-S473 phosphorylation , but not the expression of Chk2 KD , indicating that the defective KAP1 phosphorylation on S473 is caused by CCAR2 deficiency which in turn affects Chk2 activity .
Next , we assessed in these cells the repair of DNA damages induced by etoposide treatment , a chemotherapeutic drug that inhibits topoisomerase II , finally inducing double strand breaks ( DSBs ) , and that is known to strongly promote ATM and ATR dependent phosphorylation of CCAR2 and apoptosis [ XREF_BIBR ] .

Since mTOR inhibitor- induced eIF4E phosphorylation is PI3K and Mnk dependent , one strategy to improve an mTOR inhibitor 's efficacy against cancer is to prevent eIF4E phosphorylation by combining an mTOR inhibitor with a PI3K inhibitor or a Mnk inhibitor . ++++ Notably , rapamycin also failed to hyperphosphorylate eIF4E in presence of LY294002 , PI3K inhibitor , infering that mTOR pathway inhibitors may activate PI3K , leading to an increase in eIF4E phosphorylation .
We , hereby , report for the first time that 3-AWA attenuated eIF4E induced tumorigenesis by abrogating its expression as well as activation . ++++ We demonstrate here that blocking of protein translation through the inhibition of eIF4E by 3-AWA has a profound effect on c-FLIP .
Currently , different inhibitors targeting eIF4F are in clinical trials which block the activation of eIF4E by Mnk1 or prevent the association of eIF4E with eIF4G at initiation complex XREF_BIBR . ++++ But no therapeutic agent has been yet reported that could consistently suppress both the expression as well as activation of eIF4E .
Currently , different inhibitors targeting eIF4F are in clinical trials which block the activation of eIF4E by Mnk1 or prevent the association of eIF4E with eIF4G at initiation complex XREF_BIBR .

On the other hand , cellular FLICE ( FADD like IL-1beta converting enzyme )-inhibitory protein ( c-FLIP ) , a highly ubiquitous protein with a very short half life period , contributes an important role in the CaP metastasis through multi-target effects XREF_BIBR .
We also evaluated the effect of eIF4E down-regulation or translation suppression activity of 3-AWA on the translation of some of the mRNAs , proposed to be selectively regulated by eIF4E .
Given that 3-AWA inhibits c-FLIP through abrogation of translation initiation by co-targeting mTOR and Mnk-eIF4E , it ( 3-AWA ) can be exploited as a lead pharmacophore for promising anti-cancer therapeutic development .
Detailed underlying mechanisms revealed that 3-AWA inhibited Ras-Mnk and PI3-AKT-mTOR , two major pathways through which eIF4E converges upon eIF4F hub .

To further explore the mechanism of 3-AWA mediated translation suppression , we evaluated the phosphorylation and total expressions of eIF4E ( Ser -209 ) , 4EBP1 ( Thr 37/46 ) and eIF4G in 3-AWA treated PC-3 and DU145 cells through western blotting .
Since mTOR inhibitor- induced eIF4E phosphorylation is PI3K and Mnk dependent , one strategy to improve an mTOR inhibitor 's efficacy against cancer is to prevent eIF4E phosphorylation by combining an mTOR inhibitor with a PI3K inhibitor or a Mnk inhibitor .

Taken together , 3-AWA has a potential to suppress the amplifying oncogenic signals and neoplastic capabilities of a cancer cell by preventing the eIF4F mediated reprogramming of cellular translation apparatus through the blockage of its upstream pathways via eIF4E .

Paradoxically , the inhibition of mTOR signaling with rapamycin triggered eIF4E phosphorylation as evidenced by the activation of its activator Mnk1 and importantly 3-AWA abrogated rapamycin 's ability to increase eIF4E and Mnk1 phosphorylation ( XREF_FIG ) .
Notably , rapamycin also failed to hyperphosphorylate eIF4E in presence of LY294002 , PI3K inhibitor , infering that mTOR pathway inhibitors may activate PI3K , leading to an increase in eIF4E phosphorylation .
Thus , phosphorylation of 4EBP1 by mTOR leads to its association with eIF4E and hence , eIF4F complex formation , whereas inhibition of mTOR results in repression of cap dependent translation .
Our finding clearly validates that 3-AWA , through translational block , negatively modulates the expression of c-FLIP and the reliance of this c-FLIP modulation on translation initiation was strongly supported by eIF4E knockdown and over-expression studies .

Like all other small GTP binding proteins , the regulatory cycle of RhoA is controlled by three distinct families of proteins : guanine nucleotide exchange factors ( GEFs ) that activate RhoA by promoting uptake of free nucleotide , GTPase activating proteins ( GAPs ) that negatively regulate RhoA by stimulating its intrinsic GTPase activity leading to an inactive GDP bound state , and guanine nucleotide dissociation inhibitors ( GDIs ) that inhibit the dissociation of GDP from RhoA and prevent the binding of GDP-RhoA to cell membranes .
Finally , we show that regardless of the phosphorylation status of RhoA and Rac1 , substitution of the RhoA PBR with the Rac1 PBR targets RhoA to the nucleus and substitution of Rac1 PBR with RhoA PBR significantly reduces the nuclear localization of Rac1 .
We showed that EGF stimulated RhoA activation and this activation was inhibited by U0126 ( XREF_FIG ) .
It has been shown previously that Rac1 PBR ( PVKKRKRK ) , containing a nuclear localization signal ( NLS ) , promotes the accumulation of Rac1 in the nucleus , whereas RhoA PBR ( RRGKKKSG ) , without an NLS , sequesters RhoA in the cytosol [ XREF_BIBR ] .
On the other hand , RhoA PBR is able to significantly reduce the nuclear localization of Rac1 regardless of the phosphorylation status of Rac1 ( XREF_FIG ) .
We propose that by phosphorylating both RhoA and Rac1 , ERK is able to increase RhoA activity and decrease Rac1 activity .

MIG6 inhibits migration and invasion through AKT in mutant NRAS melanoma cells . ++++ Thus , inhibition of AKT reduced migration and invasion induced by MIG6 depletion in mutant NRAS melanoma cells . ++++ Functionally , we show that MIG6 negatively regulates migration and invasion ; thus , its downregulation is likely to promote pro migratory properties in tumor microenvironments containing high levels of EGF . ++++ In MEK inhibited cells , further depletion of MIG6 increased migration and invasion , whereas MIG6 expression decreased these properties .
Therefore , a decrease in MIG6 may promote the migration and invasiveness of MEK inhibited mutant NRAS melanoma especially in response to EGF stimulation . ++++ A previous phospho-proteomic analysis of a MEK inhibited mutant NRAS melanoma cell line also identified upregulation of EGFR signaling . ++++ Through RPPA analysis , we observed downregulation of MIG6 in MEK inhibited mutant NRAS melanoma that is associated with increased levels of EGFR and AKT phosphorylation .
MIG6 inhibits EGF signaling to AKT and ERK1/2 in mutant NRAS melanoma cells . ++++ Through RPPA analysis , we observed downregulation of MIG6 in MEK inhibited mutant NRAS melanoma that is associated with increased levels of EGFR and AKT phosphorylation .
We identified a role for MIG6 as a negative regulator of EGF induced AKT and ERK1/2 signaling and cell migration and invasion in mutant NRAS melanoma .
Despite the effects on EGFR signaling , the addition of EGF did not modulate growth inhibition or apoptosis induced by trametinib ( XREF_FIG ) .

Inhibition of GSK3 activity restores TGF-beta signaling in Caco-2 cells expressing endogenous Smad4 N351H . ++++ Inhibition of GSK3 activity restores TGF-beta signaling in cells expressing Smad4m130 and Smad4m351 . ++++ These results demonstrate that GSK3 chemical inhibition can reactivate TGF-beta signaling in cells harboring a point mutation ( Asn351His ) in the endogenous tumor suppressor Smad4 . ++++ We next investigated whether GSK3 inhibition could restore TGF-beta signaling in a human cancer cell line carrying a point mutation in Smad4 .
GSK3 inhibitors restored Smad4 stability and TGF-beta signaling in smad4-/- mammary tumor cells expressing Smad4 mutant proteins . ++++ They also suggest potential therapeutic applications in which pharmacological GSK3 inhibitors might stabilize Smad4 and restore TGF-beta signaling and growth control in tumors harboring such mutations .
19 Wnt signaling inhibits GSK3 activity 22,23 and therefore potentiates Smad4 activity , particularly at low concentrations of TGF-beta . ++++ 19 In the presence of Thr277 phosphorylation by MAPK and Erk , the transcriptional activity of Smad4 is maximal provided that GSK3 activity is inhibited by Wnt .
GSK3 inhibitors restored Smad4 stability and TGF-beta signaling in smad4-/- mammary tumor cells expressing Smad4 mutant proteins .
TGF-beta signaling can be reactivated provided that Smad4 rapid degradation is blocked by a GSK3 chemical inhibitor in cells that would otherwise behave as TGF-beta loss-of-function mutants .
In Caco-2 cells , which express Smad4 N351H protein , the GSK3 inhibitor LiCl was sufficient to restore TGF-beta responsiveness in a cell line that was previously impervious to TGF-beta signaling .
The findings reported here provide new insights into the mechanism by which point mutations in Smad4 cause their rapid degradation in tumor cells .
Co-transfection of Smad4-wt into these smad4-/- cells restored TGF-beta responsiveness , which was moderately increased by LiCl ( XREF_FIG , bars 1-6 ) . ++++ Since replacing Smad4m130 and Smad4m351with their GSK3 insensitive mutants eliminated LiCl potentiation , we conclude that the observed potentiation of TGF-beta by LiCl is mediated by the GSK3 phosphorylation sites of Smad4 and not by other components of the signal transduction pathway . ++++ In Caco-2 cells , which express Smad4 N351H protein , the GSK3 inhibitor LiCl was sufficient to restore TGF-beta responsiveness in a cell line that was previously impervious to TGF-beta signaling .
This hypothesis would be consistent with the proposed cycle of activation for R-Smad proteins , 29,30 and with our previous results showing that the regulation of Smad4 activity by Wnt is entirely dependent on an FGF triggered MAPK and Erk priming mechanism . ++++ This hypothesis would be consistent with the proposed cycle of activation for R-Smad proteins , 29,30 and with our previous results showing that the regulation of Smad4 activity by Wnt is entirely dependent on an FGF triggered MAPK and Erk priming mechanism .
In contrast , the low activity of Smad4m383 was not reactivated by LiCl or by mutation of its GSK3 sites ( XREF_FIG , bars 22-27 ) indicating that the Ile383Lys mutation has some functional defect in transducing the TGF-beta signal that can not be reversed by GSK3 inhibition .

One possible explanation for this observation is that the FGF induced GSK3 phosphorylations of Smad4 take place in the cytoplasm , whereas TGF-beta induced GSK3 phosphorylation of Smad4 occurs in the nucleus while Smad4 is engaged in transcription and would be independent of the Wnt and destruction complex .

Maximal TFEB activation by Torin1 is negatively regulated by the proteasome . ++++ Selectively in Torin1 treated cells , epoxomicin mediated inhibition of the proteasome leads to " Active " nuclear localization of TFEB in nearly 100 % of cells , without altering TFEB protein levels . ++++ Alternatively , proteasome inhibition might activate TFEB via induction of proteotoxic stress [ XREF_BIBR ] , which might be exacerbated under conditions of decreased mTOR activity [ XREF_BIBR ] . ++++ The mechanism by which the proteasome negatively regulates TFEB remains to be determined . ++++ During pharmacological mTOR inhibition the proteasome negatively regulates nuclear localization of TFEB .
While we show that mTOR activation maximally inhibits TFEB , mTOR inhibition only fractionally activated TFEB . ++++ Importantly , mTOR inhibition activated TFEB for a limited duration of 1.5 hours , and thereafter the cell population was progressively re-inactivated , with distinct kinetics for Torin1 and nutrient deprivation treatments . ++++ mTOR inhibition rapidly activates TFEB in a fraction of cells , for a limited duration , with distinct TFEB subpopulation re-inactivation dynamics in response to Torin1 vs. nutrient deprivation . ++++ While we show that mTOR activation maximally inhibits TFEB , mTOR inhibition only fractionally activated TFEB .
Selectively in Torin1 treated cells , epoxomicin mediated inhibition of the proteasome leads to " Active " nuclear localization of TFEB in nearly 100 % of cells , without altering TFEB protein levels . ++++ During pharmacological mTOR inhibition the proteasome negatively regulates nuclear localization of TFEB .
We first explored a possible contribution of ERK kinases , which were previously shown to negatively regulate TFEB [ XREF_BIBR ] .
Our findings suggest that the rapid rheostatic response , mediated by mTOR , allows the cell to quickly adapt to metabolic changes , while the long-term , mTOR independent homeostatic response controls the magnitude and duration of TFEB activation , and presumably limits excessive autophagy .
Strikingly , while Torin1 inhibition of mTOR was maintained for 15hours , TFEB re-inactivation began 1.5 hours following Torin1 treatment and required 15hours to inactive approximately 50 % of the population , compared to 100 % inactivation by fresh FM at 0.5 hours .
mTOR inhibition rapidly activates TFEB in a fraction of cells , for a limited duration , with distinct TFEB subpopulation re-inactivation dynamics in response to Torin1 vs. nutrient deprivation .
Torin1 mediated TFEB activation has been reported for concentrations ranging from 0.25 muM [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] to 2muM [ XREF_BIBR ] . ++++ Maximal TFEB activation by Torin1 is negatively regulated by the proteasome . ++++ Conversely in both cell types , Torin1 induced maximal TFEB nuclear concentration only in a fraction of cells , and following 1.5 hours of treatment , TFEB began a re-localization to the cytoplasm , suggesting an early rheostat control by mTOR followed by TFEB re-inactivation uncoupled from mTOR activity .
We propose an indirect pathway , in which mTOR activity inhibits proteasomal degradation of a positive TFEB regulator . ++++ The above findings reveal that mTOR maximally induced cytoplasmic TFEB retention in all HeLa cells , but fractionally in MCF7 cells .
The delay in the peak in LAMP1 concentration relative to TFEB is consistent with TFEB mediated lysosomal biogenesis . ++++ Consistent with TFEB activation of lysosomal biogenesis [ XREF_BIBR ] , the " Active " subpopulation reported higher lysosomal content than " Medium " and " Inactive " subpopulations .
Quantifying TFEB subpopulation redistributions over time , we found that with the addition of fresh FM , which mildly increased mTOR activity , TFEB heterogeneity was rapidly lost in HeLa cells .
Importantly , we found that mTOR inactivation failed to maximally activate TFEB in all cells of a cell population .
As in HeLa cells , TFEB nuclear localization and cellular concentration increased transiently in response to Torin1 and , after approximately 1hour , decreased gradually .

We investigated cell proliferation in ACHN RCC cells treated with inhibitors of mTORC1 or GSK-3 .
Generally , all the three cell lines were less sensitive to rapamycin than AR-A014418 , not having reached 50 % inhibition of cell viability from baseline even at high doses of rapamycin ( 1000 nM ) , whereas the cell lines showed a dose dependent decrease in proliferation with IC 50 between 27 and 45muM treated with AR-A014418 ( Additional file 1 : Figure S1 ) .
Treatment of rapamycin and its derivative everolimus , both of which are inhibitors of mTORC1 , reduced cell viability , and the ACHN cell viability leveled off when the concentrations of the rapalogues were higher than 10 nM .

In contrast , AR-A014418 suppressed greatly ACHN/P and ACHN/RR proliferation in concentration dependent manner .

We investigated cell proliferation in ACHN RCC cells treated with inhibitors of mTORC1 or GSK-3 .
Although rapamycin increased the G0/G1 phase in cell cycle and suppressed cell proliferation , the inhibitory effects of rapamycin on the mTORC1 downstream pathway were only transient leading to gradual return of p4EBP1 and pS6RP to the baseline level .
In contrast , AR-A014418 suppressed greatly ACHN/P and ACHN/RR proliferation in concentration dependent manner .
Moreover , pharmacological inhibition of GSK-3 was found to potentiate the anti-tumorous efficacy of sorafenib , a TKI that is used for systemic therapy of mRCC [ XREF_BIBR ] .

We previously demonstrated that GSK-3beta positively regulates the proliferation , survival , and anti-apoptosis mechanisms of cancer cells through decreased expression of the nuclear factor-kappa B target genes BCL-2 and X linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein ( XIAP ) [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] , and that nuclear accumulation of GSK-3beta could be a novel biomarker of bladder cancer [ XREF_BIBR ] and RCC [ XREF_BIBR ] .

Consistent with previous reports [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] , in the present study , we demonstrate that GSK-3beta directly phosphorylates 4EBP1 independent of rapamycin sensitivity to mTORC1 and continuously activates 4EBP1 and S6K , the mTORC1 downstream substrates to drive cell proliferation in RCC cell lines . ++++ According to Shin et al. [ XREF_BIBR ] , GSK-3beta directly phosphorylates 4EBP1 at Thr37/46 and inactivates 4EBP1 activity in breast cancer and normal cell lines , thereby increasing eIF4E dependent protein synthesis and regulating cell proliferation . ++++ GSK-3beta could directly phosphorylate 4EBP1 and activate the mTORC1 downstream signaling cascades to enhance protein biosynthesis and cell proliferation in RCC cell lines independent of rapamycin sensitivity . ++++ According to Shin et al. [ XREF_BIBR ] , GSK-3beta directly phosphorylates 4EBP1 at Thr37/46 and inactivates 4EBP1 activity in breast cancer and normal cell lines , thereby increasing eIF4E dependent protein synthesis and regulating cell proliferation . ++++ Consistent with previous reports [ XREF_BIBR , XREF_BIBR ] , in the present study , we demonstrate that GSK-3beta directly phosphorylates 4EBP1 independent of rapamycin sensitivity to mTORC1 and continuously activates 4EBP1 and S6K , the mTORC1 downstream substrates to drive cell proliferation in RCC cell lines . ++++ GSK-3beta could directly phosphorylate 4EBP1 . ++++ GSK-3beta could directly phosphorylate 4EBP1 and activate the mTORC1 downstream signaling cascades to enhance protein biosynthesis and cell proliferation in RCC cell lines independent of rapamycin sensitivity .
These results suggest that GSK-3beta could participate in the direct phosphorylation of 4EBP1 at Thr70 , Thr37/46 , and Ser65 , as reported for S6K [ XREF_BIBR ] . ++++ Therefore , we here provide the evidence that GSK-3beta can directly phosphorylate 4EBP1 at Thr37/46 , Thr70 , and Ser65 , possibly in sequential order .

In vitro kinase assays showed that recombinant GSK-3beta phosphorylated recombinant 4EBP1 , and the effect was blocked by GSK-3 inhibitors .
These results suggest that GSK-3beta could participate in the direct phosphorylation of 4EBP1 at Thr70 , Thr37/46 , and Ser65 , as reported for S6K [ XREF_BIBR ] .
Consistent with the suppression of mTORC1 signaling , we observed that cystine starvation markedly activated the ISR ( XREF_FIG ) , which inhibits global translation but selectively induces synthesis of numerous proteins involved in amino acid uptake XREF_BIBR . ++++ Supplementation of cystine suppressed the ISR as evidenced by the reduction of phospho-eIF2alpha ( S51 ) and ATF4 , but rapamycin treatment had no discernible effect ( XREF_FIG ) . ++++ We found that in hepatoma HepG2 cells , cystine ( oxidized form of cysteine ) activated mTORC1 and suppressed the ISR . ++++ Thus , cystine limitation suppressed mTORC1 and activated the ISR , the two major amino acid sensing pathways in HepG2 cells .
Given that ROS that drive ferroptosis is reduced by GSH , the effect of cystine limitation on ferroptosis is mainly ascribed to the loss of antioxidant capacity . ++++ Thus , cystine and GSH cooperate to suppress lipid ROS and ferroptosis in HepG2 cells .
Inhibition of mTORC1 pathway by rapamycin was without effect on the ISR , suggesting that mTORC1 signaling does not contribute to the ISR in this setting .
The inhibition of mTORC1 signaling by cystine starvation demonstrated that regulation of this pathway is not limited to essential amino acids XREF_BIBR XREF_BIBR XREF_BIBR XREF_BIBR , but is also regulated by cysteine availability ( XREF_FIG ) .
Thus , cystine and GSH cooperate to suppress lipid ROS and ferroptosis in HepG2 cells .
Cystine appeared to be the main regulator of GSH homeostasis ( among other amino acids ) , since cystine deprivation alone reduced intracellular GSH , and it was not further aggravated by depletion of other amino acids .
Cystine limitation increased phospho-GCN2 ( T899 ) , but not that of PERK ( as no visible mobility shift was observed ) ( XREF_FIG ) .
This is in contrast with a previous report that showed mTORC1 inhibition activated the ISR XREF_BIBR .
Inhibition of GSH degradation with OU749 , a selective GGT inhibitor XREF_BIBR , abolished the restorative effects of GSH on mTORC1 signaling and the ISR during cystine starvation ( XREF_FIG ) .
We found that cell death induced by cystine and GSH depletion was rescued by Fer-1 ( XREF_FIG ) , suggesting a role of ferroptosis .
Consistent with the suppression of mTORC1 signaling , we observed that cystine starvation markedly activated the ISR ( XREF_FIG ) , which inhibits global translation but selectively induces synthesis of numerous proteins involved in amino acid uptake XREF_BIBR .
Cystine limitation increased phospho-GCN2 ( T899 ) , but not that of PERK ( as no visible mobility shift was observed ) ( XREF_FIG ) .
Reduction of intracellular GSH alone did not activate the ISR , and cystine starvation induced a robust ISR which was not aggravated by BSO treatment ( XREF_FIG ) .
Given that cystine starvation activated the GCN2-eIF2alpha-ATF4 axis , we evaluated the expression of several AARE containing genes .
Thus , the regulation of mTORC1 by cysteine availability is critical for cells to reduce global translation to conserve amino acids and energy .
Given that cystine starvation is also known to induce ER stress XREF_BIBR , we sought to evaluate which pathway is selectively activated by cystine starvation .
Thus , exported GSH was actively degraded by GGT .
GSH preserves mTORC1 signaling activity and prevents the ISR during cystine deprivation , and this protective function is supported by its role as a cysteine storage molecule .
The transcriptional program induced by cystine deprivation is similar to that of leucine starvation XREF_BIBR , suggesting that the transcriptional program is a common adaptation of amino acid starvation to activate amino acid metabolism and stress resistance .
Thus , GSH degradation is required to prevent the stress response induced by cystine starvation in HepG2 cells .
We found that cell death induced by cystine and GSH depletion was rescued by Fer-1 ( XREF_FIG ) , suggesting a role of ferroptosis .
Re-addition of cystine restored of mTORC1 signaling , which was abolished by rapamycin ( XREF_FIG ) .
Cystine limitation increased phospho-GCN2 ( T899 ) , but not that of PERK ( as no visible mobility shift was observed ) ( XREF_FIG ) .
Supplementation of cystine restored mTORC1 signaling , and treatment with rapamycin ( a specific mTORC1 inhibitor ) abolished the induction , providing evidence for the direct role of mTORC1 in the phosphorylation of p70S6K ( T389 ) and S6 ( S235/236 ) . ++++ Thus , cystine limitation suppressed mTORC1 and activated the ISR , the two major amino acid sensing pathways in HepG2 cells . ++++ We found that in hepatoma HepG2 cells , cystine ( oxidized form of cysteine ) activated mTORC1 and suppressed the ISR .
Cystine starvation alone reduced GSH and was not further aggravated by deprivation of other amino acids , and supplementation of cystine alone was sufficient to restore GSH level in the absence of other amino acids ( XREF_FIG ) . ++++ Neither cystine starvation nor BSO induced GSH depletion alone elevated lipid ROS ( XREF_FIG ) . ++++ Cystine deprivation induced GSH efflux and extracellular degradation , which aimed to restore cellular cysteine .
Although GSH supplementation restored mTORC1 signaling and the ISR during cystine starvation , inhibition of GGT , the key enzyme responsible for ecto degradation of GSH , abolished the rescue effects of GSH ( XREF_FIG ) . ++++ Inhibition of gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase ( GGT ) impaired the ability of GSH or cell-permeable GSH to restore mTORC1 signaling and the ISR , suggesting that the capacity of GSH to release cysteine , but not GSH per se , regulated the signaling networks . ++++ Inhibition of gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase ( GGT ) impaired the ability of GSH or cell-permeable GSH to restore mTORC1 signaling and the ISR , suggesting that the capacity of GSH to release cysteine , but not GSH per se , regulated the signaling networks .
The results provided evidence that cystine is a major regulator of cellular GSH metabolism which may contribute to cystine induced cell signaling in HepG2 cells . ++++ Given that cystine and GSH balance are tightly coupled , we next evaluated whether GSH is a modulator of cystine induced cell signaling .
Inhibition of gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase ( GGT ) impaired the ability of GSH or cell-permeable GSH to restore mTORC1 signaling and the ISR , suggesting that the capacity of GSH to release cysteine , but not GSH per se , regulated the signaling networks . ++++ Inhibition of gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase ( GGT ) impaired the ability of GSH or cell-permeable GSH to restore mTORC1 signaling and the ISR , suggesting that the capacity of GSH to release cysteine , but not GSH per se , regulated the signaling networks .
Activation of the ISR elevates ATF4 to increase expression of genes which contain the amino acid response elements ( AARE ) XREF_BIBR .
Cystine starvation reduced cell viability which was severely aggravated by BSO treatment , supporting a protective role of GSH .
Although GSH supplementation restored mTORC1 signaling and the ISR during cystine starvation , inhibition of GGT , the key enzyme responsible for ecto degradation of GSH , abolished the rescue effects of GSH ( XREF_FIG ) .
Reduction of intracellular GSH alone did not activate the ISR , and cystine starvation induced a robust ISR which was not aggravated by BSO treatment ( XREF_FIG ) .
One possible explanation for such a response is that inhibition of mTORC1 and activation of GCN2 collectively suppresses global translation to conserve nutrients , while selective translation of mRNA such as ATF4 ( mediated by increased p-eIF2alpha ) activates the expression of AARE genes to mitigate cellular stress .
The marked enhancement of mTORC1 signaling by CHX was also observed in the control cells ( XREF_FIG ) , indicating that protein synthesis is the predominant amino acid consuming process in the cell .
Although GSH supplementation restored mTORC1 signaling and the ISR during cystine starvation , inhibition of GGT , the key enzyme responsible for ecto degradation of GSH , abolished the rescue effects of GSH ( XREF_FIG ) .
One possible explanation for such a response is that inhibition of mTORC1 and activation of GCN2 collectively suppresses global translation to conserve nutrients , while selective translation of mRNA such as ATF4 ( mediated by increased p-eIF2alpha ) activates the expression of AARE genes to mitigate cellular stress .
Thus , cystine starvation induces a stress signal of amino acid limitation through GCN2-eIF2alpha-ATF4 branch in the ISR but not ER stress in HepG2 cells .
Although GSH is involved in disulfide formation and protein folding in the ER XREF_BIBR , our data showed that cystine starvation did not disrupt ER homeostasis in HepG2 cells .
Thus , GSH degradation is required to prevent the stress response induced by cystine starvation in HepG2 cells .
Although GSH is involved in disulfide formation and protein folding in the ER XREF_BIBR , our data showed that cystine starvation did not disrupt ER homeostasis in HepG2 cells .
We found that cell death induced by cystine and GSH depletion was rescued by Fer-1 ( XREF_FIG ) , suggesting a role of ferroptosis .
Given that both cysteine and GSH contribute to cell metabolism , which may be a confounding factor in MTT assay , we verified the extent of cell death by propidium iodide ( PI ) staining .
Cystine starvation alone reduced GSH and was not further aggravated by deprivation of other amino acids , and supplementation of cystine alone was sufficient to restore GSH level in the absence of other amino acids ( XREF_FIG ) .
Cystine restriction elevated the level of phospho-eIF2alpha ( S51 ) and ATF4 ( XREF_FIG ) , major nodes of the ISR signaling .
Cystine limitation induced the expression of AARE containing genes in the ISR , which are involved in amino acid metabolism ( SLC7A11 , SLC7A1 , and SLC38A2 ) and cell survival ( TRIB3 ) ( XREF_FIG ) .
Cystine restriction elevated the level of phospho-eIF2alpha ( S51 ) and ATF4 ( XREF_FIG ) , major nodes of the ISR signaling .
Under cystine starved conditions , GSH supplementation rescued the phosphorylation of p70S6K ( T389 ) and S6 ( S235/236 ) of the mTORC1 pathway , and relieved the induction of phospho-GCN2 ( T899 ) , phospho-eIF2alpha ( S51 ) and ATF4 of the ISR system ( XREF_FIG ) .
Under cystine starved conditions , GSH supplementation rescued the phosphorylation of p70S6K ( T389 ) and S6 ( S235/236 ) of the mTORC1 pathway , and relieved the induction of phospho-GCN2 ( T899 ) , phospho-eIF2alpha ( S51 ) and ATF4 of the ISR system ( XREF_FIG ) .
Under cystine starved conditions , GSH supplementation rescued the phosphorylation of p70S6K ( T389 ) and S6 ( S235/236 ) of the mTORC1 pathway , and relieved the induction of phospho-GCN2 ( T899 ) , phospho-eIF2alpha ( S51 ) and ATF4 of the ISR system ( XREF_FIG ) .
Cystine starvation induced the phosphorylation of GCN2 but not PERK ( XREF_FIG ) , suggesting that cystine starvation induced the amino acid response but not the ER stress signaling within the ISR .
